intro: Wigginsia sessiliflora f. martini, commonly known as the Martini form of the sessile-flowered wigginsia, is a rare and specialized plant species within the Apiaceae family. It is characterized by its compact, herbaceous growth habit and small, clustered inflorescences. The leaves are typically sessile, meaning they lack petioles, and are arranged in a basal rosette. The flowers are usually white or pale yellow, with a distinctive umbel structure typical of the family. This subspecies is often found in rocky or arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions.
